items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
Flooding is possible today because the Yeo and Parrett rivers levels remain high and expected to continue to rise due to the further rainfall.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if the drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station exceeds 7.3m; the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m; Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and Muchelney to Drayton above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels. River Parrett levels are being managed using the Parrett relief channel. We are operating our pumping stations when river levels allow.
Avoid driving, cycling or walking through flood water. Refer to Somerset Council’s website for any local road closures.
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 19 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible for: Lower Rivers Tone and Parrett including West Moor, Hay Moor, Curry Moor, Stan Moor, Salt Moor and North Moor. The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station remains high. Water is entering Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway as this level currently exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.855m. Cutts Road floods when the drain level at Currymoor pumping station is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Please refer to the latest gauge levels on Check for Flooding and Somerset Council’s website for information on road closures in the area. Further rain is expected through Wednesday and Thursday. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High and rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Levels may continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may see levels continue to rise. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 23 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around South Street, Ludborne Road and Sherborne Sewage Treatment Works in Sherborne and the Mole Valley Farmers area on the Sherborne Road near Yeovil. High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 18 December 2025 from 13:00, as a lot of rain (32mm) fell on Thursday. 
The debris screen at Hunny Hill near Hunnycross Way is partially blocked causing a rapid rise in water level. Footpath flooding near Towngate Retail Park is possible. There is a possibility the river could come out of bank at Foxes Lane and impact the aquatics centre. Rain is forecast to continue until 16:00 on 18/12/2025. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Hunny Hill by 18:00 on 18/12/2025. 
We are clearing blockages from debris screens - Water levels will reduce rapidly once blockage has been removed. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have - Particularly properties next to the river at Vicarage Walk. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 19 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding.  
  
Flooding is expected on Thursday 18 December 2025 from around 14:00 PM 
  
Following rain throughout Wednesday and Thursday, river levels remain high. Properties and low lying areas will start to flood from around 14:00PM on Thursday. The main areas of concern are properties and low lying areas around Riverside Caravan Park at Plympton, Bickleigh Bridge, and Shaugh Bridge . Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. River levels are forecast to be at their highest between 14:00PM on Thursday and 18:00PM on Thursday. Rain is expected to ease through late Thursday evening.  
We are closely monitoring the situation .  
 Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water  
  
This message will be updated by 17:00PM on 18 December 2025 or as the situation changes.
